Vol. XXXIV, No. 50

SWARTHMORE WINS
JAY TRACK MEET
Result Of Meet Unknown Until
Last Event
FINAL SCORE IS 68-58
Jays Prove Superior In Field
Events
Hopkins track team was defeated by Swarthmore College by the
score of 68 to 58 at Homewood
Field last Saturday in a meet that
wasn't decided until the last event
was over. The Pennsylvania team
was far superior in the running
events. They scored fourteen points
in the hurdles but one should consider the fact that Hershey, the
Hopkins stellar hurdler, was out of
practise as he had just come back
from the Geology trip. Hopkins
was further handicapped by the fact
the Chassin, the star sprinter, had
not recovered from a spike wound
received during the Penn Relays.
He limped so badly that he could
not run properly. In spite of this he
came in fourth. The winning of this
race in 51.3 seconds indicates that
Chassin would have easily romped
home first under more favorable
circumstances. Howard- Jung did
his best and ran an excellent race.
Both the 220-yard low hurdles and
120-yard high hurdles were taken
by Parrish, captain of the visiting
team. Miller, two-miler, won the
event, the first victory of his college career, showing surprisingly
good form leading Emerson, a
team-mate, and Hooser of the Garnet team, to the tape. Boyer, of
the visiting team, just broke the
tape before Kelly, of the home team,
with Thompson third. Until that
time Kelly had been one of the
great mainstays of the Hopkins
team in the distance events. Because of a weak heart, however, it
is extremely unlikely that he will
run again. Lochard ran a fine race
in the 100-yard dash and placed
third behind Alden and Thomasetty,
both of Swarthmore. Alden, as
well as Parrish and Brown, were on
the team that won the Middle Atlantic States Class B mile relay
championship at the Penn Relays.

UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND FRATERNITY
FLEDGINGS DO AWAY WITH PRIZE LAYERS
Upon the dawn of the morning of
last Friday, the students of the University who were so fortunate as to
possess a newspaper and those who
were able to read, noticed that the
organization of Sigma Mu represented at Maryland by one of
its numerous chapters recently had
three chickens at an extremely
expensive banquet. The heading
indicated that the three guests cost
the group some $2,500 ano at once
the question was raised as to why so
few girls could be such a tremendous
expense for a single evening, particularly as they were in the company of fraternity men. Expensive
dates have been known to all men
in college upon certain and special
occasions, yet if this is to be the
outcome, it will greatly reduce decidedly the numerous and questionable dates of students of many and
numerous seats of learning.
It seems that the difficulty started at some indefinite time last fall,
and the profound secret was kept
below decks until recently when
three pairs of highly-prized legs
were discovered in an ash barrel be-

hind the house. A brutal and horrible execution had mercilessly taken
place during the last year.

MUSICAL CLUB HOLDS
BANQUET, ELECTION
At the annual banquet of
the Musical Club held last Saturday night at the Southern
Hotel, the election of officers
for the ensuing year was held.
Bruce Peake was the choice of
the members and will succeed
Martin A. Elliott, as president
for next year.
Kenneth Sharretts a n d
Mike Donovan were elected as
junior managers for next year.
Following the custom established some years ago, certifiicates were awarded to all the
members of the club. The gathering was entertained by a
humorous speech by "Os"
Steinwald.
Following the banquet, the
club held a dance for its members in the main ball room of
the Southern Hotel.

However, detectives were summoned and quickly presented the solution to the mystery and stated that
the legs originally were possessed
by no less than the excellent hens
of a tremendous egg-laying capacity. They had been secretly seduced
by the same number of evasive
freshmen pledges and brought to the
brothers as a sacrifice to their appetites. And thus it appears that it
would be a noble idea for fraternity
men to closely observe their unfortunate pledges and watch the movements of freshmen who seem to
have an unusual attraction tor those
of the opposite sex. Whether this is
the case because of the nonchalance
or merely because of general stupidity and timidness of the freshmen,
has notas yet been determined, but
it is a safe wager that pledges will
not again be sent forth upon a quest
to abduct females in the near future

Dr. C. Singer Speaks On
Hullabaloo Due To

Appear On June]. Doubles Match Defaulted
Last week, Dr. Charles Singer,
lecturer in the History of Medicine
at the University College, London,
gave a series of lectures on "The
Transition from Midiaeval to Modern Science." Among those who
heard his presentations were many
well known physicians of Baltimore
and students of both the Medical
and undergraduate school. These
lectures were held in the auditorium
of the School of Hygiene and Public Health, 615 N. Wolf street.
On January 8, 1929, Dr. Emanual
Libman of New York City, donated
a fund to the Johns Hopkins University to endow a lectureship in
the history of medicine, in memory
of the late Dr. Hideyo Noguchi,
who died in Africa while investigating the cause of yellow fever. The
trustees of the Johns Hopkins University chose Dr. Charles Singers
this year, as the first to render a
subject under this lectureship.

According to George Gump,
chairman of the Board of Editors,
the 1930 Hullabaloo is due to appear on the campus on June 1. This
is the date that was originally set
for its appearance and at the present time things are running smoothly and the work is up to date. Unless something unforseen looms up.
which will delay the work, it will
come out on time this year.
When the Hullabaloos come to
the University from the printers,
they will be placed in the custody
of John Myers and a copy will be
given to each person upon the presentation of his Student Activities
card to Mr. Myers at the postoffice.
All persons who desire a copy of
the year book but who have no Student Activities card are requested to
get in touch with George Gettemuller immediately.
Those men who intend to leave
the University before its official
closing can be assured of receiving a
copy by giving their name and address, Student Activities card and a
few cents to cover postage to Mr.
Myers, before their departure. However the Hullabaloo will be out before the official closing of the University and in time to be distributed
to all the students who do not leave
early.

Friday afternoon, on the Homewood courts, the University of Virginia netmen trounced the Hopkins
raquet-wielders by a score of 7 to 2.
This is the second defeat the Jay
team has received from the Southern team. The first match, played
at Charlottesville, having resulted
just as disastrously for the Black
and Blue players.
Hopkins Strong Opposition

JAY LACROSSE TEAM
DEFEATSPRINCETON
Fast, Smooth Working Attack,
Steady Defense Cause Tiger
Downfall
SCORE 7-0
Weitzel, Hopkins; Campbell,
Princeton; Outstanding
Men For Teams
Saturday the Johns Hopkins lacrosse team scored its sixth victory
of the season by defeating the
Princeton team to the tune of 7-0
at the Homewood Field.
Starting after about three minutes of feeling around the Jay attack began to cut through the visiting defense to shoot at will. It was
only the stellar playing of Campbell,
at goal, that saved the Tigers from
being whitewashed by a quota
score.
Turnbull Starts Scoring

After the opening - whistle the
Princeton men surged toward the
Jay goal and took a shot which was
stopped by Ferrarini. The defense
cleared the ball nicely and then the
Blue team began to show its color.
After playing around the Orange
and Black goal, looking for an
opening, Dukeheart finally got the
ball out on the side of the field.
Turnbull came steaming across the
field, a line of defense men chasing
him, received a pass from Dukeheart and scored up the first tally
Of the game.
Stone took the next face off and
started, tornado fashion, for the
Princeton goal. He was checked,
however, was forced to change his
course and head for the side. The
rest of the attack formed and the
ball was passed around until Dukeheart again passed the pellet to the
man who scored the goal. Stone
was left by his defense man long
enough for him to receive a pass
and deliver the goal. Some ten minutes after this, with the ball bounding out of a melee, Stone raced after it, uncovered it, and gunned it
passed the goalie so fast that the
goal net was nearly torn from the
pipes.

take off stuffy clothing (do the girls
these days wear stuffy clothing?)
and get into scanty bathing suits
(we are right about the scanty bathing suits, anyway). Luckily, the
Johns Hopkins June Week Committee has scheduled its beach party
on this day.
All the Hopkins seniors, most of
the undergrads and many alumni
get into cars or buses about 3
o'clock with their girls and head for
the Chesapeake. After a ride that
is really too short to become tiresome they arrive at Pinehurst-onthe-Bay and see the cool, limpid
waters of the Chesapeake looming
up before them. If you can remember how you felt along about
the second hour of lab last Wednesday afternoon you begin to realize
what a joyful sight the Chesapeake
will be to our June Weekers. But the
water isn't all; Pinehurst provides
a bathing house that seems just a
trifle larger than the Fifth Regiment Armory, spacious lawns where
one may lounge around in the
shade, and a large dance hall that
promises much fun for the evening.

A bit more of historic excitement
has been recently added to the
archives of the Alumni Memorial
Dormitory with the passing of the
freshman and sophomore banquet
seasons. Hostilities were opened a
little over a week past with the customary various and sundry types of
violence, and before the conclusion
of the period of warfare, the resident students of the two lower
classes were taking the utmost advantages afforded by the somewhat
questionable security of their respective rooms. At length, a truce was
declared by the two classes on the
premises of the Hall, which allowed those upon the defensive a bit
more freedom of movement, at least
to meals. This last point had been a
favorite with the beseigers as they
soon discovered that even the most
timid and peaceful individuals must
necessarily have their share of food.

Many and numerous heroic deeds
are to be cited upon the sides of
both respective classes, such as a

Fraternities at Lehigh having
ratings below 1.6 will be on probation-at the last faculty meeting, it

into effect with the start of the next
college year. Under the new system, any living group averaging below 1.6 for a successive semester.

the next succeeding semester, or
until it has obtained a group average of 1.6 or better.

Dorm Asks Sergeant
For Sunday Baseball
Due to the fact that there is a
scarcity of tennis courts, a group
of dormitory residents petitioned
Sergeant Frank to allow them to indulge in Sunday baseball on the
campus. Some years ago the trustees of the University banned all
Sunday sports. A few years ago the
ban on tennis was lifted.
The sergeant plans to present this
petition before the president of the
University, tomorrow. If the petition is granted Sergeant Frank, who
is an ardent baseball fan, plans to
organize and coach one or two
campus teams, which will play on
the lower field behind the M. E.
and C. E. buildings each Sunday.

SWARTHMORE WINS
JAY TRACK MEET
Result Of Meet Unknown Until
Last Event
FINAL SCORE IS 68-58
Jays Prove Superior In Field
Events
Hopkins track team was defeated by Swarthmore College by the
score of 68 to 58 at Homewood
Field last Saturday in a meet that
wasn't decided until the last event
was over. The Pennsylvania team
was far superior in the running
events. They scored fourteen points
in the hurdles but one should consider the fact that Hershey, the
Hopkins stellar hurdler, was out of
practise as he had just come back
from the Geology trip. Hopkins
was further handicapped by the fact
the Chassin, the star sprinter, had
not recovered from a spike wound
received during the Penn Relays.
He limped so badly that he could
not run properly. In spite of this he
came in fourth. The winning of this
race in 51.3 seconds indicates that
Chassin would have easily romped
home first under more favorable
circumstances. Howard- Jung did
his best and ran an excellent race.
Both the 220-yard low hurdles and
120-yard high hurdles were taken
by Parrish, captain of the visiting
team. Miller, two-miler, won the
event, the first victory of his college career, showing surprisingly
good form leading Emerson, a
team-mate, and Hooser of the Garnet team, to the tape. Boyer, of
the visiting team, just broke the
tape before Kelly, of the home team,
with Thompson third. Until that
time Kelly had been one of the
great mainstays of the Hopkins
team in the distance events. Because of a weak heart, however, it
is extremely unlikely that he will
run again. Lochard ran a fine race
in the 100-yard dash and placed
third behind Alden and Thomasetty,
both of Swarthmore. Alden, as
well as Parrish and Brown, were on
the team that won the Middle Atlantic States Class B mile relay
championship at the Penn Relays.

UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND FRATERNITY
FLEDGINGS DO AWAY WITH PRIZE LAYERS
Upon the dawn of the morning of
last Friday, the students of the University who were so fortunate as to
possess a newspaper and those who
were able to read, noticed that the
organization of Sigma Mu represented at Maryland by one of
its numerous chapters recently had
three chickens at an extremely
expensive banquet. The heading
indicated that the three guests cost
the group some $2,500 ano at once
the question was raised as to why so
few girls could be such a tremendous
expense for a single evening, particularly as they were in the company of fraternity men. Expensive
dates have been known to all men
in college upon certain and special
occasions, yet if this is to be the
outcome, it will greatly reduce decidedly the numerous and questionable dates of students of many and
numerous seats of learning.
It seems that the difficulty started at some indefinite time last fall,
and the profound secret was kept
below decks until recently when
three pairs of highly-prized legs
were discovered in an ash barrel be-

hind the house. A brutal and horrible execution had mercilessly taken
place during the last year.

MUSICAL CLUB HOLDS
BANQUET, ELECTION
At the annual banquet of
the Musical Club held last Saturday night at the Southern
Hotel, the election of officers
for the ensuing year was held.
Bruce Peake was the choice of
the members and will succeed
Martin A. Elliott, as president
for next year.
Kenneth Sharretts a n d
Mike Donovan were elected as
junior managers for next year.
Following the custom established some years ago, certifiicates were awarded to all the
members of the club. The gathering was entertained by a
humorous speech by "Os"
Steinwald.
Following the banquet, the
club held a dance for its members in the main ball room of
the Southern Hotel.

However, detectives were summoned and quickly presented the solution to the mystery and stated that
the legs originally were possessed
by no less than the excellent hens
of a tremendous egg-laying capacity. They had been secretly seduced
by the same number of evasive
freshmen pledges and brought to the
brothers as a sacrifice to their appetites. And thus it appears that it
would be a noble idea for fraternity
men to closely observe their unfortunate pledges and watch the movements of freshmen who seem to
have an unusual attraction tor those
of the opposite sex. Whether this is
the case because of the nonchalance
or merely because of general stupidity and timidness of the freshmen,
has notas yet been determined, but
it is a safe wager that pledges will
not again be sent forth upon a quest
to abduct females in the near future

Last week, Dr. Charles Singer,
lecturer in the History of Medicine
at the University College, London,
gave a series of lectures on "The
Transition from Midiaeval to Modern Science." Among those who
heard his presentations were many
well known physicians of Baltimore
and students of both the Medical
and undergraduate school. These
lectures were held in the auditorium
of the School of Hygiene and Public Health, 615 N. Wolf street.
On January 8, 1929, Dr. Emanual
Libman of New York City, donated
a fund to the Johns Hopkins University to endow a lectureship in
the history of medicine, in memory
of the late Dr. Hideyo Noguchi,
who died in Africa while investigating the cause of yellow fever. The
trustees of the Johns Hopkins University chose Dr. Charles Singers
this year, as the first to render a
subject under this lectureship.

According to George Gump,
chairman of the Board of Editors,
the 1930 Hullabaloo is due to appear on the campus on June 1. This
is the date that was originally set
for its appearance and at the present time things are running smoothly and the work is up to date. Unless something unforseen looms up.
which will delay the work, it will
come out on time this year.
When the Hullabaloos come to
the University from the printers,
they will be placed in the custody
of John Myers and a copy will be
given to each person upon the presentation of his Student Activities
card to Mr. Myers at the postoffice.
All persons who desire a copy of
the year book but who have no Student Activities card are requested to
get in touch with George Gettemuller immediately.
Those men who intend to leave
the University before its official
closing can be assured of receiving a
copy by giving their name and address, Student Activities card and a
few cents to cover postage to Mr.
Myers, before their departure. However the Hullabaloo will be out before the official closing of the University and in time to be distributed
to all the students who do not leave
early.

Friday afternoon, on the Homewood courts, the University of Virginia netmen trounced the Hopkins
raquet-wielders by a score of 7 to 2.
This is the second defeat the Jay
team has received from the Southern team. The first match, played
at Charlottesville, having resulted
just as disastrously for the Black
and Blue players.

Steady Defense Cause Tiger
Downfall
SCORE 7-0
Weitzel, Hopkins; Campbell,

Saturday the Johns Hopkins lacrosse team scored its sixth victory
of the season by defeating the
Princeton team to the tune of 7-0
at the Homewood Field.
Starting after about three minutes of feeling around the Jay attack began to cut through the visiting defense to shoot at will. It was
only the stellar playing of Campbell,
at goal, that saved the Tigers from
being whitewashed by a quota
score.
Turnbull Starts Scoring

After the opening - whistle the
Princeton men surged toward the
Jay goal and took a shot which was
stopped by Ferrarini. The defense
cleared the ball nicely and then the
Blue team began to show its color.
After playing around the Orange
and Black goal, looking for an
opening, Dukeheart finally got the
ball out on the side of the field.
Turnbull came steaming across the
field, a line of defense men chasing
him, received a pass from Dukeheart and scored up the first tally
Of the game.
Stone took the next face off and
started, tornado fashion, for the
Princeton goal. He was checked,
however, was forced to change his
course and head for the side. The
rest of the attack formed and the
ball was passed around until Dukeheart again passed the pellet to the
man who scored the goal. Stone
was left by his defense man long
enough for him to receive a pass
and deliver the goal. Some ten minutes after this, with the ball bounding out of a melee, Stone raced after it, uncovered it, and gunned it
passed the goalie so fast that the
goal net was nearly torn from the
pipes.

take off stuffy clothing (do the girls
these days wear stuffy clothing?)
and get into scanty bathing suits
(we are right about the scanty bathing suits, anyway). Luckily, the
Johns Hopkins June Week Committee has scheduled its beach party
on this day.
All the Hopkins seniors, most of
the undergrads and many alumni
get into cars or buses about 3
o'clock with their girls and head for
the Chesapeake. After a ride that
is really too short to become tiresome they arrive at Pinehurst-onthe-Bay and see the cool, limpid
waters of the Chesapeake looming
up before them. If you can remember how you felt along about
the second hour of lab last Wednesday afternoon you begin to realize
what a joyful sight the Chesapeake
will be to our June Weekers. But the
water isn't all; Pinehurst provides
a bathing house that seems just a
trifle larger than the Fifth Regiment Armory, spacious lawns where
one may lounge around in the
shade, and a large dance hall that
promises much fun for the evening.

A bit more of historic excitement
has been recently added to the
archives of the Alumni Memorial
Dormitory with the passing of the
freshman and sophomore banquet
seasons. Hostilities were opened a
little over a week past with the customary various and sundry types of
violence, and before the conclusion
of the period of warfare, the resident students of the two lower
classes were taking the utmost advantages afforded by the somewhat
questionable security of their respective rooms. At length, a truce was
declared by the two classes on the
premises of the Hall, which allowed those upon the defensive a bit
more freedom of movement, at least
to meals. This last point had been a
favorite with the beseigers as they
soon discovered that even the most
timid and peaceful individuals must
necessarily have their share of food.

are to be cited upon the sides of

Fraternities at Lehigh having
ratings below 1.6 will be on probation-at the last faculty meeting, it
was decided that the ruling will go
into effect with the start of the next
college year. Under the new system, any living group averaging below 1.6 for a successive semester.
shall be denied social privileges for
the next succeeding semester, or
until it has obtained a group average of 1.6 or better.

Dorm Asks Sergeant
For Sunday Baseball
Due to the fact that there is a
scarcity of tennis courts, a group
of dormitory residents petitioned
Sergeant Frank to allow them to indulge in Sunday baseball on the
campus. Some years ago the trustees of the University banned all
Sunday sports. A few years ago the
ban on tennis was lifted.
The sergeant plans to present this
petition before the president of the
University, tomorrow. If the petition is granted Sergeant Frank, who
is an ardent baseball fan, plans to
organize and coach one or two
campus teams, which will play on
the lower field behind the M. E.
and C. E. buildings each Sunday.
